entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+ship%5C%3A+Cache+sharing+for+extremely%5C-pervasive+resources%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 08:49:58 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>Thanks for pointing out Mozilla's response. I think they have some fair </tt><tt>points. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>If we look at the list, it is clear from domain names, that some sites, </tt><tt>or entities, will benefit more from others from faster first-loads. I </tt><tt>mean, something like 30% of the list are from Google entities, from very </tt><tt>harmless (IMHO) hosted fonts to analytics, ads and video hosting </tt><tt>(YouTube). Some other big sites like Shopify and Wix/parastorage combine </tt><tt>to another 15%. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>Having your key resources on that list may not matter very much, or it </tt><tt>may. The existence of the list is scary and I lack the data to </tt><tt>understand what the pros are both in scale and area. Is the disk space </tt><tt>issue a real problem or just something that is a potential concern </tt><tt>lacking investigation, for instance? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>I understand that the published list is not a final, set-in-stone, item, </tt><tt>so I will not comment on individual items, but what thought have there </tt><tt>been on maintaining such a list long term? It seems to me that it might </tt><tt>become an area of contention that would be nice to avoid. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>In the initial intent, the claim was that this is important for the </tt><tt>healthy operation of the web. But is it really? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Daniel
On 2025-10-22 15:43, Patrick Meenan wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>FYI, I updated Chromestatus with Mozilla's position on the feature </tt><tt>(strongly negative). It's not a platform-exposed feature but they do </tt><tt>have concerns that they wanted to note in a position issue </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1231">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1231</a>>. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On Sat, Oct 18, 2025 at 8:34 AM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="25554840400b0b0b65464d574a484c50480b4a5742">[email protected]</a>> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Sorry, I missed a step in making the candidate resource list public. I have moved it to my chromium account and made it public here
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TgWhdeqKbGm6hLM9WqnnXLn-iiO4Y9HTjDXjVO2aBqI/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TgWhdeqKbGm6hLM9WqnnXLn-iiO4Y9HTjDXjVO2aBqI/edit?usp=sharing</a>>.
Not everything in that list meets all of the criteria - it's just the first step in the manual curation (same URL served the same content across > 20k sites in the HTTP Archive dataset).
The manual steps frome there for meeting the criteria are basically:
- Cull the list for scripts, stylesheets and compression dictionaries. - Remove any URLs that use query parameters. - Exclude any responses that set cookies. - Identify URLs that are not manually versioned by site embedders (i.e. the embedded resource can not get stale). This is either in-place updating resources or automatically versioned resources. - Only include URLs that can reliably target a single resource by pattern (i.e. ..../<hash>-common.js but not ..../<hash>.js) - Get confirmation from the resource owner that the given URL Pattern is and will continue to be appropriate for the single-keyed cache
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 7:02 PM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1e6e737b7b3030305e7d766c7173776b7330716c79">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Assuming we have the privacy and security concerns under control (which we're pretty confident is the case for the extremely small subset of resources we are talking about), the main discussion point is the balancing of incentives and "playing favorites".
As you noted, the performance impact is relatively small but it's not non-zero when you get to the scale of some of the resources we are talking about (like <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.google-analytics.com/analytics.js">https://www.google-analytics.com/analytics.js</a> which is on 10M of the pages in the 50M page HTTP Archive dataset). This isn't really a framework discussion because those kinds of resources aren't a good fit for the restrictions that are in place for the privacy and security protections but there is a discussion about providing network benefits to specific third-parties that cross the pervasive threshold and meet the rest of the conditions (for at least part of the library).
The question is if the marginal performance benefit that can only be realized at that level of scale (where a given user would be likely to have the current version of that specific library in cache) would be a meaningful competitive factor for a newcomer (vs features, ease of use, pricing, mindshare, etc).
That also gets balanced against the user benefit of not having to keep re-downloading the exact same thing and from having to keep dozens of copies of it in cache, cached with different cache keys (taking cache space away from other resources).
There's also a more nuanced benefit that allows for federation of a feature across domains vs centralizing the experience. For example, Shopify and Wix's platform libraries show up in the candidate list as they are used by hundreds of thousands of sites in the CrUX dataset. Having a shared cache for those libraries would put them into a more competitive position against centralized platforms (Amazon, Etsy, Blogger, etc) while still allowing sites to own the overall experience.
I guess that's the long way of saying "it's complicated but we feel pretty strongly that the theoretical risk in this case is more than offset by the platform benefits".
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 5:15 PM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="ea9a878f8fc4c4c4aa8982988587839f87c485988d">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Nothing is being pre-populated (other than the list of URL patterns). When a "pervasive" resource is encountered naturally by a given user, it will be stored in a single-keyed cache instead of a site/frame/url-keyed cache (reducing storage duplication for that specific resource for that specific user).
The linked doc has all of the mitigations in place, but the big one for explicit tracking is that it can only be used when full cookie access is also allowed, otherwise it falls through to the fully-partitioned cache.
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 4:58 PM Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="12617e7b757a667e6b3c3c3c52717a607d7f7b677f3c7d6075">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
This is interesting, given all of the problems involved in governance and the way it cuts against platform progress <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://infrequently.org/2022/03/cache-and-prizes/">https://infrequently.org/2022/03/cache-and-prizes/</a>>. Will the full set be downloaded before any pre-population is used? What controls will be in place to make sure that this does not exacerbate cross-site tracking via timing? Will these caches be pushed in a versioned way? Who will make the call about how much can be in the set? And are these delivered via component-updater?
Best,
Alex
On Friday, October 17, 2025 at 1:44:19 PM UTC-7 Patrick Meenan wrote:
I expect it will change over time but the changes should be pretty minor (as new resources increase or decrease popularity). Generally we'd want to include resources that have been common for a while and are likely to continue to be common. I'd expect small changes every milestone (or two). There's also the <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4c3c293e3a2d3f253a29612f2d6262620c2f243e232125392162233e2b">[email protected]</a> mailing list that you can ping to give us a heads-up (or a CL to Chromium) if there's something specific you want to draw attention to.
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 4:33 PM Ben Kelly <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="483f29262c2d3a3e66666608252d3c29662b2725">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Thank you. Do you expect the list of resources to change over time? Will http archive data be analyzed for every milestone release?
*From: *Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6f1f020a0a4141412f0c071d0002061a0241001d08">[email protected]</a>> *Date: *Friday, October 17, 2025 at 4:30 PM *To: *Ben Kelly <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="cabdaba4aeafb8bce4e4e48aa7afbeabe4a9a5a7">[email protected]</a>> *Cc: *blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1e7c72777075337a7b685e7d766c7173776b7330716c79">[email protected]</a>> *Subject: *Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
This Message Is From an External Sender Yes. The list will be committed directly to the Chromium repository. The list of candidate resources (before the manual vetting) is in a sheet here
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hXYVqwHQJJVTJ3LnKwMZiGF-eFGHc1J8y8k3Xc7h8zc/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!5dVWGFYASzLWqT-IVHrc7lq1pVJyQ3AMs4O-AkEt6daUAkc_lPuOdm000ap-M0eOLyAF5EjjHFZsGcbwoQ$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hXYVqwHQJJVTJ3LnKwMZiGF-eFGHc1J8y8k3Xc7h8zc/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!5dVWGFYASzLWqT-IVHrc7lq1pVJyQ3AMs4O-AkEt6daUAkc_lPuOdm000ap-M0eOLyAF5EjjHFZsGcbwoQ$</a>>.
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 4:15 PM Ben Kelly <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="89fee8e7edecfbffa7a7a7c9e4ecfde8a7eae6e4">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Will the list of manually curated scripts be published somewhere? I did not immediately see something like this skimming the doc or chrome status entry.
Thanks.
Ben
*From: *Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d2a2bfb7b7fcfcfc92b1baa0bdbfbba7bffcbda0b5">[email protected]</a>> *Date: *Friday, October 17, 2025 at 3:12 PM *To: *blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c5a7a9acabaee8a1a0b385a6adb7aaa8acb0a8ebaab7a2">[email protected]</a>> *Subject: *[blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
This Message Is From an External Sender *Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6c1c0109094242422c0f041e030105190142031e0b">[email protected]</a>
*Specification* /N/A/
*Design docs*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJhFCuXRtQ$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJhFCuXRtQ$</a>>
*Summary* For a small number (hundreds) of hand-curated static third-party script, stylesheet and compression-dictionary resources that are used on a large portion of the web, Chrome will use a single-keyed HTTP cache to store those resources.
This helps users and site owners with faster performance for those resources that are very widely used while maintaining the privacy protections of the partitioned disk cache. This feature targets the resources that most users are likely to see multiple times across multiple sites in any given browsing session. They are usually not in the critical path of the page loading and may not impact the common performance metrics but they are still important for the healthy operation of the web.
The list of candidate resources is manually curated from the HTTP Archive dataset and updated on an ongoing basis. This includes site-independent things like common analytics scripts, social media embeds, video player embeds, captcha providers and ads libraries.
It allows for code that uses versioned URLs as long as the versioning is not a manual process by embedders and that the same version is sent to everybody at a given point in time with the same contents. This does not include things like common Javascript libraries where they are commonly self-hosted or where the URL references a specific version of the library and it is up to site owners to manually select a version.
i.e.

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Performance + Event Timing: InteractionCount
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Performance + Event Timing: InteractionCount
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Performance+%5C%2B+Event+Timing%5C%3A+InteractionCount%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Performance + Event Timing: InteractionCount</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 08:41:30 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="264b4b4908080866414949414a430845494b">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount</a>
Design docs No information provided <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#sec-increasing-interaction-count">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#sec-increasing-interaction-count</a>
Summary The Event Timing API is part of the Performance Timeline and is used to measure the performance of user interactions. Certain Events will have an interactionId value assigned to them, and this is useful for grouping related interactions based on common physical user inputs or gestures. This feature adds a very trivial performance.interactionCount, which is just the total number of interactions that have occured on the page. In particular, this feature is useful for computing the Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric value, which requires knowing the total number of interactions in order to compute a high percentile score (p98 for pages with greater than 50 total interactions). This feature has been specced for a long while, was prototypes in Chromium a long time ago but never shipped, is part of Interop 2025, and is already available in other browsers. (Note: there is already a more powerful performance.eventCounts map for specific events, but it is not possible to accurately map event cunts to interaction counts.)
Blink component Blink>PerformanceAPIs
Web Feature ID event-timing
Motivation Used to count the number of important real user interactions with a page. This is distinct from counting the number of events that Event Timing measures (because a single physical user gesture may fire many, variable number, of specific events, depending on the type of input and event target and page design) but you can already count interactions (inconveniently) by just counting the number of unique interactionId values in Event Timing API. Used for calculating Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric.
Initial public proposal No information provided
TAG review No information provided
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility Other browser venders have already shipped this feature as part of the Interop 2025 effort for CWV INP. The main interop risk is that there are existing polyfills for interactionCount in Chromium for INP calculation. However, popular polyfills (such as web-vitals.js) have long been tested to feature detect, given the long experimental web platform implementation in chromium.
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/xvv6sxJZc4U/m/JzSSCoxPAgAJ?e=48417069">https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/xvv6sxJZc4U/m/JzSSCoxPAgAJ?e=48417069</a>)
WebKit: In development (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=297361">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=297361</a>)
Web developers: Strongly positive No specific link, but this feature is related to the very popular INP metric definition (and obviates the need for an imperfect polyfill for counting interactions).
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? n/a
Debuggability DevTools has existing support for Interactions (real time performance monitor and tracing). Visualizing total interactionCount is not needed, but can be easily found (via literally counting the list of interactions, or just console logs).
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/event-timing/">https://wpt.fyi/results/event-timing/</a> (several tests, look for interaction-count-*)
Flag name on about://flags No information provided
Finch feature name EventTimingInteractionCount
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Availability expectation Feature is available on Web Platform Baseline within 12 months of launch in Chrome (as part of Interop 2025 for INP)
Adoption expectation Polyfill already widely adopted (for INP calculation), and feature detection already used.
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 143
DevTrial on desktop 111
Shipping on Android 143
DevTrial on Android 111
Shipping on WebView 143
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). Already specced in Event Timing API.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153386492198912?gate=5819984274128896">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153386492198912?gate=5819984274128896</a>

To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/68f8fb21.050a0220.39dfc1.1a8d.GAE%40google.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/68f8fb21.050a0220.39dfc1.1a8d.GAE%40google.com</a>. </pre>

Summary Shows elastic overscroll effects on non-root scroll containers. When a nested scrollable element reaches its scroll boundary, the overscroll affordance applies to that element instead of only the root scroller. This reduces the need for custom Javascript workarounds and can be controlled per element with overscroll-behavior.

Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility This feature is not developer-observable and presents no compatibility risk. Firefox and Safari already ship elastic overscroll effects for non-root scroll containers.

Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes Only platforms with an overscroll effect will get one on non-root scrollers.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? No

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Web+Authentication+Conditional+Create+%5C%28Automatic+Passkey+Upgrades%5C%29%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Web Authentication Conditional Create (Automatic Passkey Upgrades)</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20260115" rel="nofollow">Thu, 15 Jan 2026 12:57:16 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="f39e9281879addddddb3949c9c949f96dd909c9e">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-credential-management/#dom-credentialmediationrequirement-conditional:~:text=For%20create">https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-credential-management/#dom-credentialmediationrequirement-conditional:~:text=For%20create</a>
Summary WebAuthn Conditional Create allows websites to automatically create passkeys for existing users that have a matching password saved in their password manager.
Blink component Blink>WebAuthentication
Web Feature ID No information provided
Motivation WebAuthn Conditional Create requests let a website (aka a Relying Party or RP) create a passkey without prominent modal mediation, if the user has previously consented to credential creation. The motivating use case is commonly referred to as "passkey upgrades". Ie, if the browser/credential manager already stores an existing password credential for the same website/relying party and user, conditional create allows the the website automatically create a matching passkey. An explainer with more information is hosted in the W3C WebAuthn wiki: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/webauthn/wiki/Explainer:-Conditional-Registration-Extension">https://github.com/w3c/webauthn/wiki/Explainer:-Conditional-Registration-Extension</a>
Initial public proposal No information provided
TAG review No information provided
TAG review status Issues addressed
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility WebKit already shipped this feature ahead of Blink, so this launch is positive for interoperability.
Gecko: No signal
WebKit: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-release-notes/safari-18-release-notes#Authentication:~:text=Implemented%20conditional%20credential%20creation.%20">https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-release-notes/safari-18-release-notes#Authentication:~:text=Implemented%20conditional%20credential%20creation.%20</a>)
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? No information provided
Debuggability No information provided
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes Blink implements this feature on all platforms. On Android, requests are forwarded to the native Credential Manager API, where supporting password managers need to implement it separately.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/webauthn/conditional-mediation.https.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/webauthn/conditional-mediation.https.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
Flag name on about://flags No information provided
Finch feature name No information provided
Non-finch justification No information provided
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/377758786">https://crbug.com/377758786</a>
Launch bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4373425">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4373425</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 136
Shipping on Android 142
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). No information provided
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5135710007590912?gate=5163515357429760">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5135710007590912?gate=5163515357429760</a>
Links to previous Intent discussions Intent to Prototype: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/67329059.2b0a0220.26ec07.069d.GAE%40google.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/67329059.2b0a0220.26ec07.069d.GAE%40google.com</a> Ready for Trial: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/XFJmqtQpMds/m/ipPKSS5ECQAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/XFJmqtQpMds/m/ipPKSS5ECQAJ</a>

To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/696954a4.050a0220.f8796.0375.GAE%40google.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/696954a4.050a0220.f8796.0375.GAE%40google.com</a>. </pre>

entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Update Device Memory API limits
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Update+Device+Memory+API+limits%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Update Device Memory API limits</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20260121" rel="nofollow">Wed, 21 Jan 2026 08:15:57 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM3
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2026-01-21 17:14, Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2
On Wednesday, January 21, 2026 at 5:03:36 PM UTC+1 Barry Pollard wrote:
Done. Apologies as I thought API reviewers approved first (my first feature change!).
On Wed, 21 Jan 2026 at 15:49, Vladimir Levin <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="f6809b86d8d8d8b6959e84999b9f839bd8998491">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Hey,
Can you please request various review chips as well? (Privacy, Security, etc)
Thanks, Vlad
On Tuesday, January 20, 2026 at 3:11:47 PM UTC-5 <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a1c3c0d3d3d8d18f8f8fe1c6cecec6cdc48fc2cecc">[email protected]</a> wrote:
It seems like a bit of a design footgun to have different thresholds across platforms, and we do see 16+GB Androids very commonly, so I'm wondering if we can't use a unified list in the update?
I'm not averse to keeping them the same and this is something I brought up with the WebPerf WG when I discussed this as I too would have preferred not to have different limits.
However, saying that, 16GB on Android still seems super rare from our own internal stats (unfortunately I don't have approval to share exact details) and 32GB even more so. Rarer in fact than some of the values I'm proposing dropping here for privacy reasons. I've also looked at this globally, and again that introduces more concerns for certain regions.
Then again, they may not be rarer than the 8GB was when the original API was added. And, as you point out, they are only likely to become more common.
If you and the other API owners feel strongly about this, I can speak to Privacy about this (and they'll need to sign this off anyway) and/or seek permission to get stats to share. But my personal point of view is with the limits I've recommended for now, despite the fact they differ between device type. Hopefully with the precedent being set here, and some of the spec work to make this easier to update in the future having been completed already, adding 16GB or above when the time is right won't be as big or a burden in the future.
As you know, it has been an ongoing frustation of mine that these values (and those for networks in netinfo) are so outdated.
I did wonder about netInfo when making this change, but personally I've become convinced that the ECT buckets are not good and not worth updating. I think the RTT value is a better one (and in Chrome ECT is currently only based on RTT anyway since Downlink proved less reliable, so doesn't match the spec) and doesn't require updating. So my preference is to retire ECT and depend on RTT instead, perhaps with non-normative advice on how to group them into categories. But anyway, that's off topic.
On Tue, 20 Jan 2026 at 19:53, Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3a4956535d524e56431414147a5952485557534f571455485d">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
First, wanted to thank you deeply for pushing this forward, Barry. As you know, it has been an ongoing frustation of mine that these values (and those for networks in netinfo) are so outdated.
It seems like a bit of a design footgun to have different thresholds across platforms, and we do see 16+GB Androids very commonly, so I'm wondering if we can't use a unified list in the update?
Regardless, a grateful LGTM1 from me.
Best,
Alex
On Monday, January 19, 2026 at 4:02:59 PM UTC-8 <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="f89a998a8a8188d6d6d6b89f97979f949dd69b9795">[email protected]</a> wrote:
It seems to me that the privacy concerns with this and similar APIs are primarily concerned with random webpages. In the case of installed PWA, IWA, WebExtension, etc, which have a higher level of trust, it makes sense to me that the values could be untruncated, both retaining those smaller values and perhaps also going upwards beyond 32. What do you think?
Potentially, though I'm not sure we have precedent for this? Or if that risks its own web compatibility concerns and risks (e.g. functionality that works differently, or not at all, depending on whether it's installed or not).
Can you explain the use case/value of knowing beyond below 2GB or beyond 32GB at this point? I'm not sure I can see a pressing need based on my knowledge of how the API is used, and the limited value small numbers, outside of the current values, delivers.
Also whether you'd also be looking for a more granular breakdown between the currently coarsened values (e.g. knowing if it's 24GB as opposed to 16GB that would currently be reported with this change). The latter would require a spec change though because although the capping is noted as independent the "power-of-two" levels is not. So any such change would need to be discussed with the Web Perf Working Group first of all by opening an issue on the spec repo: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues</a>>
On Mon, 19 Jan 2026 at 23:49, Daniel Herr <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="82e6e3ecebe7eeeae7f0f0f1ede4f6f5acacacc2e5efe3ebeeace1edef">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
It seems to me that the privacy concerns with this and similar APIs are primarily concerned with random webpages. In the case of installed PWA, IWA, WebExtension, etc, which have a higher level of trust, it makes sense to me that the values could be untruncated, both retaining those smaller values and perhaps also going upwards beyond 32. What do you think?
On Mon, Jan 19, 2026, 5:52 PM 'Barry Pollard' via blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="12707e7b7c793f76776452717a607d7f7b677f3c7d6075">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
*Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6a080b1818131a0506064444442a0d05050d060f44090507">[email protected]</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#ccaeadbebeb5bca3a0a0e2e2e28caba3a3aba0a9e2afa3a1">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="eb898a9999929b848787c5c5c5ab8c84848c878ec5888486">[email protected]</span></a>> *Summary* Set a new set of possible values for the Device Memory API: - Android: 2, 4, 8 - Others: 2, 4, 8, 16, 32 Replacing the old values of 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 8 which have grown outdated.
This will reduce the fingerprinting risks at the lower end since device capabilities have improved since these were set.
It will also allow better usage and segmenting of high-end devices as requested by developers (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50</a>>).
*Blink component* Blink>JavaScript>API
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EJavaScript%3EAPI%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EJavaScript%3EAPI%22</a>>
*Web Feature ID* device-memory <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webstatus.dev/features/device-memory">https://webstatus.dev/features/device-memory</a>>
*Search tags* DeviceMemory
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:DeviceMemory">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:DeviceMemory</a>>, memory <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:memory">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:memory</a>>, Sec-CH-DeviceMemory
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:Sec-CH-DeviceMemory">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:Sec-CH-DeviceMemory</a>>
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility* While this does not introduce a new API and the values were somewhat* non-standardised the current values have been around for some time for Chromium-based browsers (the only implementor at this time).
* Note: the ambiguity has been cleared up in the spec to make it super clear the values are implementation-defined and so subject to change.
As such , I foresee two risks here: - Some web apps have gated some features on < 2GB RAM and these devices will now start to report as the minimum 2GB RAM and so enable features the devices may not be capable of using. - Some webpages may have incorrectly coded to presume no value >8 will ever be reported.
The compatibility risk here however seems small, and the privacy risk of remaining as is is not small.
However the feature has been gated behind a feature flag so, should the worst happen, we can revert to the original values.
/Gecko/: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/g/mozilla.dev.platform/c/cfydu35XdnY/m/3IqYn0oJAQAJ">https://groups.google.com/g/mozilla.dev.platform/c/cfydu35XdnY/m/3IqYn0oJAQAJ</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/g/mozilla.dev.platform/c/cfydu35XdnY/m/3IqYn0oJAQAJ">https://groups.google.com/g/mozilla.dev.platform/c/cfydu35XdnY/m/3IqYn0oJAQAJ</a>>) Firefox didn't go as far as giving a negative signal AFAIK but have raised concerns. They have not blocked updating these limits.
/WebKit/: Negative (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/24">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/24</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/24">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/24</a>>) Webkit are negative to the original API but have not blocked updating these limits.
/Web developers/: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50</a>>) Proposal
/Other signals/: This was discussed in the WebPerf WG group on 2026-01-15 and we were in agreement to change this.
*Ergonomics* Very low-end devices may no longer be excluded from features web developers have previously restricted to >= 2GB RAM.
*Activation* None, other than those noted in Interoperability and compatibility risks.
*Security* Internal stats were reviewed to confirm the lower bounds are rarely used and so present a privacy risk.
This was also confirmed with discussions with external RUM providers.
Additionally the new upper bounds were decided upon based on similar data review (internal only, since these values are not currently exposed—which is what we are trying to fix).
Finally, the upper bounds are not planned to be increased (yet) on Android since >8GB RAM is still rare for mobile devices.
*WebView application risks*
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
Kill switch (kUpdatedDeviceMemoryLimitsFor2026) included.
*Debuggability* The feature is available from standard APIs, but it is not currently possible to emulate the values (since that will only change the reported value and not the amount of RAM used so is of limited use).
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?* Yes Note different values on Android and other platforms
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?* Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/device-memory?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/device-memory?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/device-memory?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/device-memory?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>>
These tests will be updated as part of this change
(<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.git.corp.google.com/c/chromium/src/+/7410045">https://chromium-review.git.corp.google.com/c/chromium/src/+/7410045</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.git.corp.google.com/c/chromium/src/+/7410045">https://chromium-review.git.corp.google.com/c/chromium/src/+/7410045</a>>).
*Flag name on about://flags* /No information provided/
*Finch feature name* kUpdatedDeviceMemoryLimitsFor2026
*Non-finch justification* I am not planning on rolling this out via finch giving the low risk, but will include a feature flag (`kUpdatedDeviceMemoryLimitsFor2026`) to allow it to be turned off if the worst should happen.
*Requires code in //chrome?* False
*Tracking bug* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/454354290">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/454354290</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/454354290">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/454354290</a>>
*Measurement* This is already track with an existing use counters: - JS API -
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2121">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2121</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2121">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2121</a>> - Client Hints:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4046">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4046</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4046">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4046</a>> - Client Hints (deprecated name):
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2017">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2017</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2017">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2017</a>>
*Availability expectation* Feature is available only in Chromium browsers for the foreseeable future.
*Adoption expectation* RUM Providers using this feature can validate increased usefulness of the new values.
*Adoption plan* Present at RUM CG on the change and ask for feedback after implementation.
*Non-OSS dependencies*
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function?
No
*Estimated milestones* Shipping on desktop 146 Shipping on Android 146 Shipping on WebView 146
*Anticipated spec changes*
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
Spec issues resolved: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/pull/53">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/pull/53</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/pull/53">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/pull/53</a>>
*Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/6330376953921536">https://chromestatus.com/feature/6330376953921536</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/6330376953921536">https://chromestatus.com/feature/6330376953921536</a>>

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Update+Device+Memory+API+limits%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Update Device Memory API limits</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Andy+Luhrs%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Andy Luhrs' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20260121" rel="nofollow">Wed, 21 Jan 2026 13:29:53 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>This came up at TPAC - I think the rough consensus was it makes sense to be a recurring TPAC session for the WebPerfWG specs. ________________________________ From: Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b0c3dcd9d7d8c4dcc99e9e9ef0d3d8c2dfddd9c5dd9edfc2d7">[email protected]</a>> Sent: Wednesday, January 21, 2026 8:51 AM To: blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="57353b3e393c7a33322117343f25383a3e223a79382530">[email protected]</a>> Cc: Daniel Bratell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="bedcccdfcadbd2909090fed9d3dfd7d290ddd1d3">[email protected]</a>>; <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6a080b1818131a4444442a0d05050d060f44090507">[email protected]</a> <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="412320333338312e2d2d6f6f6f01262e2e262d246f222e2c">[email protected]</a>>; <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b2d6d3dcdbd7dedad7c09c9c9cf2d5dfd3dbde9cd1dddf">[email protected]</a> <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6d090c0304080105081f1f1e020b191a4343432d0a000c0401430e0200">[email protected]</a>>; Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0477686d636c70687d2a2a2a44676c766b696d71692a6b7663">[email protected]</a>>; Vladimir Levin <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="50263d207e7e7e103338223f3d39253d7e3f2237">[email protected]</a>>; Yoav Weiss <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="acd5c3cddadbc9828282eccfc4dec3c1c5d9c182c3decb">[email protected]</a>> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Update Device Memory API limits</pre><pre>
Excited that this will ship. Thanks for the response about thresholds and the user population, Barry. I'll trust your best judgement here.
It does re-open the question of how we can get the various WGs that have maintenance responsibility to occasionally revisit these lists. Perhaps something we should discuss with the TAG?
Best,
Alex
On Wednesday, January 21, 2026 at 8:16:03 AM UTC-8 Daniel Bratell wrote:
LGTM3
/Daniel
On 2026-01-21 17:14, Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) wrote: LGTM2
On Wednesday, January 21, 2026 at 5:03:36 PM UTC+1 Barry Pollard wrote: Done. Apologies as I thought API reviewers approved first (my first feature change!).
On Wed, 21 Jan 2026 at 15:49, Vladimir Levin <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5e28332e7070701e3d362c3133372b3370312c39">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#07716a7729292947646f75686a6e726a29687560">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3d4b504d1313137d5e554f525054485013524f5a">[email protected]</span></a>>> wrote: Hey,
Can you please request various review chips as well? (Privacy, Security, etc)
Thanks, Vlad
On Tuesday, January 20, 2026 at 3:11:47 PM UTC-5 <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="ef8d8e9d9d969fc1c1c1af88808088838ac18c8082">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#47252635353e3769696907202828202b226924282a">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="53313221212a237d7d7d13343c3c343f367d303c3e">[email protected]</span></a>> wrote: It seems like a bit of a design footgun to have different thresholds across platforms, and we do see 16+GB Androids very commonly, so I'm wondering if we can't use a unified list in the update?
I'm not averse to keeping them the same and this is something I brought up with the WebPerf WG when I discussed this as I too would have preferred not to have different limits.
However, saying that, 16GB on Android still seems super rare from our own internal stats (unfortunately I don't have approval to share exact details) and 32GB even more so. Rarer in fact than some of the values I'm proposing dropping here for privacy reasons. I've also looked at this globally, and again that introduces more concerns for certain regions.
Then again, they may not be rarer than the 8GB was when the original API was added. And, as you point out, they are only likely to become more common.
If you and the other API owners feel strongly about this, I can speak to Privacy about this (and they'll need to sign this off anyway) and/or seek permission to get stats to share. But my personal point of view is with the limits I've recommended for now, despite the fact they differ between device type. Hopefully with the precedent being set here, and some of the spec work to make this easier to update in the future having been completed already, adding 16GB or above when the time is right won't be as big or a burden in the future.
As you know, it has been an ongoing frustation of mine that these values (and those for networks in netinfo) are so outdated.
I did wonder about netInfo when making this change, but personally I've become convinced that the ECT buckets are not good and not worth updating. I think the RTT value is a better one (and in Chrome ECT is currently only based on RTT anyway since Downlink proved less reliable, so doesn't match the spec) and doesn't require updating. So my preference is to retire ECT and depend on RTT instead, perhaps with non-normative advice on how to group them into categories. But anyway, that's off topic.
On Tue, 20 Jan 2026 at 19:53, Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d2a1bebbb5baa6beabfcfcfc92b1baa0bdbfbba7bffcbda0b5">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#d1a2bdb8b6b9a5bda8ffffff91b2b9a3bebcb8a4bcffbea3b6">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="73001f1a141b071f0a5d5d5d33101b011c1e1a061e5d1c0114">[email protected]</span></a>>> wrote: First, wanted to thank you deeply for pushing this forward, Barry. As you know, it has been an ongoing frustation of mine that these values (and those for networks in netinfo) are so outdated.
It seems like a bit of a design footgun to have different thresholds across platforms, and we do see 16+GB Androids very commonly, so I'm wondering if we can't use a unified list in the update?
Regardless, a grateful LGTM1 from me.
Best,
Alex
On Monday, January 19, 2026 at 4:02:59 PM UTC-8 <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a4c6c5d6d6ddd48a8a8ae4c3cbcbc3c8c18ac7cbc9">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#e6848794949f96c8c8c8a6818989818a83c885898b">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="63010211111a134d4d4d23040c0c040f064d000c0e">[email protected]</span></a>> wrote: It seems to me that the privacy concerns with this and similar APIs are primarily concerned with random webpages. In the case of installed PWA, IWA, WebExtension, etc, which have a higher level of trust, it makes sense to me that the values could be untruncated, both retaining those smaller values and perhaps also going upwards beyond 32. What do you think?
Potentially, though I'm not sure we have precedent for this? Or if that risks its own web compatibility concerns and risks (e.g. functionality that works differently, or not at all, depending on whether it's installed or not).
Can you explain the use case/value of knowing beyond below 2GB or beyond 32GB at this point? I'm not sure I can see a pressing need based on my knowledge of how the API is used, and the limited value small numbers, outside of the current values, delivers.
Also whether you'd also be looking for a more granular breakdown between the currently coarsened values (e.g. knowing if it's 24GB as opposed to 16GB that would currently be reported with this change). The latter would require a spec change though because although the capping is noted as independent the "power-of-two" levels is not. So any such change would need to be discussed with the Web Perf Working Group first of all by opening an issue on the spec repo: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues</a>
On Mon, 19 Jan 2026 at 23:49, Daniel Herr <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="385c5956515d54505d4a4a4b575e4c4f161616785f55595154165b5755">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#b2d6d3dcdbd7dedad7c0c0c1ddd4c6c59c9c9cf2d5dfd3dbde9cd1dddf">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d0b4b1beb9b5bcb8b5a2a2a3bfb6a4a7fefefe90b7bdb1b9bcfeb3bfbd">[email protected]</span></a>>> wrote: It seems to me that the privacy concerns with this and similar APIs are primarily concerned with random webpages. In the case of installed PWA, IWA, WebExtension, etc, which have a higher level of trust, it makes sense to me that the values could be untruncated, both retaining those smaller values and perhaps also going upwards beyond 32. What do you think?
On Mon, Jan 19, 2026, 5:52 PM 'Barry Pollard' via blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="01636d686f6a2c656477416269736e6c68746c2f6e7366">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#4f2d23262124622b2a390f2c273d2022263a2261203d28">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="2e4c42474045034a4b586e4d465c4143475b4300415c49">[email protected]</span></a>>> wrote: Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0b696a7979727b6467672525254b6c64646c676e25686466">[email protected]</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#a2c0c3d0d0dbd2cdcece8c8c8ce2c5cdcdc5cec78cc1cdcf">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a2c0c3d0d0dbd2cdcece8c8c8ce2c5cdcdc5cec78cc1cdcf">[email protected]</span></a>> Summary Set a new set of possible values for the Device Memory API: - Android: 2, 4, 8 - Others: 2, 4, 8, 16, 32 Replacing the old values of 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 8 which have grown outdated.
This will reduce the fingerprinting risks at the lower end since device capabilities have improved since these were set.
It will also allow better usage and segmenting of high-end devices as requested by developers (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50</a>).
Blink component Blink>JavaScript>API<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EJavaScript%3EAPI%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EJavaScript%3EAPI%22</a>>
Web Feature ID device-memory<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webstatus.dev/features/device-memory">https://webstatus.dev/features/device-memory</a>>
Search tags DeviceMemory<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:DeviceMemory">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:DeviceMemory</a>>, memory<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:memory">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:memory</a>>, Sec-CH-DeviceMemory<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:Sec-CH-DeviceMemory">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:Sec-CH-DeviceMemory</a>>
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility While this does not introduce a new API and the values were somewhat* non-standardised the current values have been around for some time for Chromium-based browsers (the only implementor at this time).
* Note: the ambiguity has been cleared up in the spec to make it super clear the values are implementation-defined and so subject to change.
As such , I foresee two risks here: - Some web apps have gated some features on < 2GB RAM and these devices will now start to report as the minimum 2GB RAM and so enable features the devices may not be capable of using. - Some webpages may have incorrectly coded to presume no value >8 will ever be reported.
The compatibility risk here however seems small, and the privacy risk of remaining as is is not small.
However the feature has been gated behind a feature flag so, should the worst happen, we can revert to the original values.
Gecko: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/g/mozilla.dev.platform/c/cfydu35XdnY/m/3IqYn0oJAQAJ">https://groups.google.com/g/mozilla.dev.platform/c/cfydu35XdnY/m/3IqYn0oJAQAJ</a>) Firefox didn't go as far as giving a negative signal AFAIK but have raised concerns. They have not blocked updating these limits.
WebKit: Negative (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/24">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/24</a>) Webkit are negative to the original API but have not blocked updating these limits.
Web developers: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/issues/50</a>) Proposal
Other signals: This was discussed in the WebPerf WG group on 2026-01-15 and we were in agreement to change this.
Ergonomics Very low-end devices may no longer be excluded from features web developers have previously restricted to >= 2GB RAM.
Activation None, other than those noted in Interoperability and compatibility risks.
Security Internal stats were reviewed to confirm the lower bounds are rarely used and so present a privacy risk.
This was also confirmed with discussions with external RUM providers.
Additionally the new upper bounds were decided upon based on similar data review (internal only, since these values are not currently exposed—which is what we are trying to fix).
Finally, the upper bounds are not planned to be increased (yet) on Android since >8GB RAM is still rare for mobile devices.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
Kill switch (kUpdatedDeviceMemoryLimitsFor2026) included.
Debuggability The feature is available from standard APIs, but it is not currently possible to emulate the values (since that will only change the reported value and not the amount of RAM used so is of limited use).
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes Note different values on Android and other platforms
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/device-memory?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/device-memory?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
These tests will be updated as part of this change (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.git.corp.google.com/c/chromium/src/+/7410045">https://chromium-review.git.corp.google.com/c/chromium/src/+/7410045</a>).
Flag name on about://flags No information provided
Finch feature name kUpdatedDeviceMemoryLimitsFor2026
Non-finch justification I am not planning on rolling this out via finch giving the low risk, but will include a feature flag (`kUpdatedDeviceMemoryLimitsFor2026`) to allow it to be turned off if the worst should happen.
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/454354290">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/454354290</a>
Measurement This is already track with an existing use counters: - JS API - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2121">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2121</a> - Client Hints: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4046">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4046</a> - Client Hints (deprecated name): <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2017">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/2017</a>
Availability expectation Feature is available only in Chromium browsers for the foreseeable future.
Adoption expectation RUM Providers using this feature can validate increased usefulness of the new values.
Adoption plan Present at RUM CG on the change and ask for feedback after implementation.
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function?
No
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop 146 Shipping on Android 146 Shipping on WebView 146
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
Spec issues resolved: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/pull/53">https://github.com/w3c/device-memory/pull/53</a>
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/6330376953921536">https://chromestatus.com/feature/6330376953921536</a>
